intro: Quercus charcasana, commonly known as the Chiripá oak, is a deciduous tree native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. The plant is characterized by its lobed leaves, which are typically dark green on the upper surface and lighter on the underside. It produces small, cupule-enclosed acorns that serve as a food source for various wildlife. Quercus charcasana plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, contributing to forest structure and biodiversity.
